Dose (per administration).
Exposure Dose Unit
Unit
Record the unit of dose or amount taken per period recorded (e.g., ng, mg, mg/kg).

Unit of dose or amount taken per constant dosing interval recorded. Dose unit must be collected if it cannot be determined via other methods (e.g., from protocol, randomization data). The unit should be pre-printed on the CRF or a field provided on the CRF to capture it. A CDASH Subset Controlled Terminology Codelist Name is available for general dose and volume units.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
The unit for intended dose (per administration) for EXDOSE, EXDOSTOT, or EXDOSTXT.
Exposure Dosing Frequency per Interval
Frequency
Record the frequency the study treatment was administered for a defined period of time.

This may be collected if it cannot be determined from other sources or if there are multiple options. When possible, the options for dose/amount frequency are pre-printed on the CRF. When collected, the recommendation is to collect dosing information in separate fields (e.g., ECDOSE, ECDOSEU, ECDOSFRQ) for specific and consistent data collection and to enable programmatically using these data.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
The number of doses given/administered/taken during a specific interval.
Exposure Route of Administration
Route
Record the route of administration (e.g., IV, ORAL, TRANSDERMAL) or enter the appropriate code from the code list.
This may be collected if it cannot be determined via other methods (e.g., from protocol) or if there are multiple options.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
The route of administration of the study treatment.
Intended Dose Regimen
Intended Dose Regimen
Record the regimen for the study medication.

The regimen information may further clarify the dose administration and dose frequency (e.g., TWO WEEKS ON, TWO WEEKS OFF). This may be pre-printed or collected. The sponsor may wish to create a codelist to collect this data consistently.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
The text description of the intended schedule or regimen for the Intervention.
Dose Adjusted
(Dose) Adjusted
Select either Yes or No to indicate whether there was a change in dosing.

Typically, the intent/purpose of collecting this field is to help with data cleaning and monitoring, as it provides a definitive response regarding any dose changes. It provides verification that the associate field on the CRF (EXADJ) was deliberately left blank. However, the sponsor may collect whether the dose was adjusted, without collecting the reason for the change.

When EXADJ is collected, does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM annotated CRF indicates that this field is NOT SUBMITTED. When EXADJ is not collected, the sponsor may submit this variable as a SUPPQ.
An indication of whether the dose was adjusted.
Reason for Dose Adjustment
Reason Adjusted
If there was a change in dosing, record the reason for change.

Captures the reason the dose was changed or modified. The reason may be chosen from a sponsor-defined list (e.g., adverse event, insufficient response) or entered as free text. May be used for variations from protocol-specified doses or changes from expected doses.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Description of or explanation for why a dose of the study treatment was adjusted.
EX Exposure Interrupted
[(Study) Treatment / Dose] Interrupted
Record if there was an interruption in the study treatment or dosing.

The intent/purpose of collecting this field is to help with data cleaning and monitoring when the actual duration of the exposure is collected using the CDASH field EXCINTD. In some situations, if the actual duration of the interruption is not collected, or not derived, this information could be submitted in a SUPPEX.QVAL dataset where SUPPEX.QNAM = "EXITRPYN" and SUPPEX.QLABEL = "Exposure Interrupted".
Does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM annotated CRF indicates that this field is NOT SUBMITTED.
An indication of whether the exposure was interrupted.
Exposure Interruption Duration
(Interruption) Duration
Record the duration of treatment interruption.
In some situations, the duration of the interruption may be calculated from the administration start and end times recorded elsewhere in the CRF.

This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPEX dataset as the value of SUPPEX.QVAL where SUPPEX.QNAM="EXITRPD" and SUPPEX.QLABEL= "Interruption Duration". Concatenate the collected treatment interruption duration and the duration unit components and create EXITRPD using ISO 8601 Period format. Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of non-standard variables (NSVs) in SDTM domains.
The collected duration of the treatment interruption.
Exposure Interruption Duration Units
(Interruption Duration) Unit
Record the unit (e.g., MINUTES, HOURS, DAYS) for the duration of treatment interruption.
The unit should be collected and converted into ISO 8601 period format.

This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPEX dataset as the value of SUPPEX.QVAL where SUPPEX.QNAM = "EXITRPD" and SUPPEX.QLABEL= "Interruption Duration". Concatenate the collected treatment interruption duration and the duration unit components and create EXITRPDusing ISO 8601 Period format. Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains.
The unit for the collected duration of treatment interruption.
Exposure Location of Dose Administration
Anatomical Location
Record the body location where the study treatment was administered (e.g., SHOULDER, HIP, ARM).

Collected or pre-printed when the sponsor needs to identify the specific anatomical location where the study treatment was administered. LAT, DIR, PORTOT are used to further describe the anatomical location.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
A description of the anatomical location of administration.
Exposure Vehicle Amount
Total Amount
Record the total amount (treatment +vehicle) that was administered/given to the subject.
Administration amount that was given to the subject. Note: should not be the diluent amount alone. The ECTRTV field may be collected if it cannot be determined from other sources.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. The SDTM variable ECTRTV may also be populated during the process of creating the SDTM submission datasets.
The amount of the prepared product (treatment + vehicle) administered or given.
Exposure Vehicle Amount Units
Unit
Record the unit of total amount (treatment +vehicle) administered/given to the subject (e.g., mL).
Unit of the administration amount. A CDASH Subset Controlled Terminology Codelist Name is available for dose and volume units.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
The unit of measure for the prepared product (treatment + vehicle).
Exposure Infusion Rate
Infusion Rate
Record the Rate of Infusion (e.g., if rate is 10 mL/min. Record 10 as the infusion rate).
The infusion rate can be used to derive dose.

This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPEX dataset as the value of SUPPEX.QVAL where SUPPEX.QNAM = "EXFLRT" and SUPPEX.QLABEL= "Infusion Rate". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains.
The flow rate for the total amount of drug + vehicle administered to the subject.
Exposure Infusion Rate Unit
(Infusion Rate) Unit
Record the unit for the infusion rate (e.g., mL/min).
Unit of the infusion rate

This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPEX dataset as the value of SUPPEX.QVAL where SUPPEX.QNAM ="EXFLRTU" and SUPPEX.QLABEL="Infusion Rate Unit". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains.
The unit of measure for the flow rate for the total amount of drug + vehicle administered to the subject.
Exposure Planned Time Point Name
[Planned Time Point Name]
Record the planned time point of study treatment administration if not pre-printed on the CRF.

Planned time points are needed to differentiate multiple sequential assessments. It is recommended that time points should be pre-printed on the CRF rather than collected in a field that requires the site to enter text. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Planned Time Point" can be included in the column heading.

Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. See the SDTMIG for additional information on representing time points. The SDTMIG time-point anchors EXTPTREF (text description) and EXRFTDTC (date/time) may be needed, as well as SDTMIG variables EXTPTNUM, EXELTM.
A text description of the planned time point when measurements should be taken, as defined in the protocol.
Completed Treatment
Completed Treatment
Select either Yes or No to indicate whether subject has completed the full course of treatment.
Depending on how the study treatment details are collected via the CRF/eCRF, it may be possible to derive those data if the regimen data are collected.

This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPEX dataset as the value of SUPPEX.QVAL where SUPPEX.QNAM = "EXTRTCMP" and SUPPEX.QLABEL=" Completed Treatment". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains.
Indication of whether the subject completed the intended regimen.
Exposure Laterality
Side
Record the side of the body location where the study treatment was administered (e.g., Left, Right).

Further details the laterality of the location where the study treatment was administered. This may be pre-printed or collected. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Qualifier for anatomical location, further detailing side of the body for the study treatment administration.
Exposure Directionality
Directionality
Record the directionality of the body location where the study treatment was administered (e.g., Anterior, Lower, Proximal, Upper).

May be pre-printed or collected when the sponsor needs to identify the directionality of the anatomical location. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Qualifier further detailing the position of the anatomical location, relative to the center of the body, organ, or specimen.
Study Identifier
[Protocol/Study]

Although this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or in the EDC system. This field can be included into the database or populated during SDTM-based dataset creation before submission.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
A unique identifier for a study.
Study Site Identifier
Site (Identifier)

Paper: This is typically pre-printed in the header of each CRF page for single-site studies. For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be pre-printed on CRFs that are shipped to each site. \n EDC: This should be prepopulated.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
A unique identifier for a site within a study.
Subject Identifier for the Study
[Subject/Participant] (Identifier)
Record the identifier for the subject.

Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be system generated. This CDASH variable is typically collected in all CDASH domains. However, this CDASH variable is populated only in the SDTMIG DM domain. For more information, refer to the SDTMIG.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
A unique subject identifier within a site and a study.
Category for Meal
[Meal/Food Product] Category]; NULL
Record the [meal/food product] category, if not pre-printed on the CRF.

Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading, or a pre-printed category value on the CRF and not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Category" can be included as the column header.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
A grouping of topic-variable values based on user-defined characteristics.
Subcategory for Meal
[Meal/Food Product] Subcategory]; NULL
Record the [meal/food product] subcategory, if not pre-printed on the CRF.

Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be pre-printed on the CRF or screen and prepopulated in the data management system. This is not typically a question to which the site would provide an answer.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
A sub-division of the MLCAT values based on user-defined characteristics.
Any Meal Taken
Any [meal/food product] [taken/consumed/administered] ?
Indicate if the subject consumed any [meal/food product]. If Yes, include the appropriate details where indicated on the CRF.
The intent/purpose of collecting this field is to help with data cleaning and monitoring. It provides verification that all other fields on the CRF were deliberately left blank.
Does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM annotated CRF indicates that this field is NOT SUBMITTED.
An indication of whether any meal or food product were consumed or administered.
ML Sponsor-Defined Identifier
[Sponsor defined]
If collected on the CRF, the sponsor may insert instructions to ensure each record has a unique identifier.

Because SPID is a sponsor-defined identifier, conformance to Question Text or Item Prompt is not applicable. Typically used as an identifier in a data query to communicate clearly to the site the specific record in question or to reconcile meal/food product records with AEs and/or MH. May be used to record pre-printed number (e.g. line number, record number) on the CRF. This field may be populated by the sponsor's data collection system.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.

A sponsor-defined identifier. In CDASH, this is typically used for pre-printed or auto-generated numbers on the CRF, or any other type of identifier that does not already have a defined CDASH identifier field.
Name of Meal or Food Product
[Meal]
Record only 1 [meal/food product name] per line.
Sponsors may use the name of a food or the name of the combination of foods (e.g., breakfast, low-fat meal, breakfast bar, water). \n
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
The reported name of the food, beverage or combination of food or beverage consumed at one time. \n
ML Pre-specified

For pre-specified interventions, a hidden field on a CRF defaulted to "Y", or added during the SDTM dataset creation. If a study collects both pre-specified and free-text interventions, the value of MLPRESP should be "Y" for all pre-specified interventions and null for interventions reported as free text.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
An indication that a specific intervention or a group of interventions is pre-specified on a CRF.
ML Occurrence
[MLTRT]
Indicate if [MLTRT] was [taken/consumed/administered] by checking Yes or No.

MLOCCUR is used to report the occurrence of a pre-specific meal/ food product. MLOCCUR is not used for spontaneously reported free-text meals/food products. The site should be able to indicate that the response was not asked or answered.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. If the question was not asked or answered, populate the SDTMIG variable MLSTAT with "NOT DONE".
An indication of whether the pre-specified meal or food product were taken/consumed/administered when information about the occurrence of the specific intervention was solicited.
Reason for Occur Value
Reason for Occur Value
Reason [MLTRT] (Not) [Performed/Taken/Done/Administered]

The reason MLTRT occurred may be chosen from a sponsor-defined codelist or entered as free text. When --REASOC is used, --OCCUR must also be populated in the SDTM dataset. This variable should not be used to represent that the item was "NOT ANSWERED ", "NOT DONE." "NOT COMPLETED" or "UNKNOWN". The variables MLSTAT /MLREASND should be used instead.

This information could be submitted in a SUPPML dataset as the value of SUPPML.QVAL where SUPPML.QNAM = "MLREASOC" and SUPPML.QLABEL ="Reason for Occur Value". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of non-standard variables (NSVs) in SDTM domains.
An explanation for why the scheduled intervention did or did not occur.
ML Reason
Reason
Record the reason the meal/product was taken.

This is the condition, disease, symptom, or disorder for which the meal or food product is taken/consumed/administered This additional information is collected on the CRF when sponsors want to capture the reason(s) why a subject took a meal/product.

This information could be submitted in a SUPPML dataset as the value of SUPPML.QVAL where SUPPML.QNAM = "MLREAS" and SUPPML.QLABEL ="Reason for the Intervention". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains.
The reason that the meal/food product was used.
Related Clinical Event ID
Clinical Event Identifier
Record the identifier of the Clinical Event for which this [meal/food product] was taken/consumed/administered.

The intent is to establish a link between the meal/food product and a clinical event that was reported. MLCENO can be used to identify a relationship between records in ML dataset and records in the CE dataset. See the SD for information on RELREC.
This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission datasets, may be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in the CE domain.
Identifier for the clinical event event that is the indication for this meal or food product.
Dose
[Quantity/Amount] (given at one time)
Record the quantity/amount of the meal/food product (e.g., --TRT ) given at one time represented as a numeric value.
Used when the quantity taken/administered/consumed has only numeric entries. If non-numeric entries are possible, use the CDASH field MLDSTXT.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
The quantity/amount of the meal or food product (e.g., --TRT) taken/consumed/administered represented as a numeric value.
Dose Description
Dose
Record the quantity/amount of the [meal/food product] taken/consumed/administered at one time.

Defining this data collection field as a text field allows for flexibility in capturing entries as numbers, text, or ranges. The data collected in this text-format field should be separated or mapped to either SDTMIG MLDOSE (if numeric) or MLDOSTXT (if text).
This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. Numeric values map to MLDOSE in SDTM. Non-numeric values (e.g., 200-400) map to MLDOSTXT in SDTM.
The quantity/amount of the meal or food product (e.g., --TRT) taken/consumed/administered represented as a numeric or text value.
Dose Units
(Quantity/Amount) Unit
Record the unit for the quantity/amount of the [meal/food product] taken/consumed/administered.
When sponsors collect data for amount /quantity of meal/food product taken (i.e., Dose, Total Daily Dose), the unit must be collected as well (if applicable).
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
The unit associated with the quantity/amount of the the meal /food product taken/consumed/administered.
Meal Start Date
(Start) Date
Record the date the [meal/food product] was first taken/consumed/administered using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).

The assumption is that sponsors should either have a start date or will indicate that the meal or food product was started before, during, or after the study period. The preferred method is to collect a complete start date. Partial dates (e.g., providing year only) for meal/food product started a considerable amount of time prior to the start of study are acceptable.

This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH START DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable MLSTDTC in ISO 8601 format.
The start date when the meal or food product was first taken/consumed/administered, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Meal Start Time
Start Time
Record the time (as complete as possible) that the [meal/food product] was started.

Recommend collecting the time a meal/food product was started only when a protocol or data collection scenarios supports it. Typically, a start time is not collected unless the subject is under the direct care of the site at the time a meal/food product or the subject records the start time in a diary. See Section 3.7, Mapping Relative Times from Collection to Submissions, and the SDTMIG for more information.

This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH START DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable MLSTDTC in ISO 8601 format.
The time the meal or food product was started, represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss).
Meal End Date
End Date
Record the date the [meal/food product] was stopped using this format (DD-MON-YYYY). If the subject has not stopped taking the [meal/product] leave this field blank.

The assumption is that sponsors should either have an end date or will indicate that the meal or food product was ongoing at the time of collection or at the end of the study. However, in cases where the end date can be determined from dates collected elsewhere in the CRF it is not necessary to include an end date in the CRF.

This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH END DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable MLENDTC in ISO 8601 format.
The date that the subject ended/stopped taking/consuming/administering the meal or food product product represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Meal End Time
End Time
Record the time (as complete as possible) that the [meal/food product] was stopped.

Recommend collecting the time a meal/food product was ended only when a protocol or data collection scenarios require it or the subject records the start time in a diary. Typically, a end time is not collected unless the subject is under the direct care of the site at the time a meal/food product or the subject records the end time in a diary. See Section 3.7, Mapping Relative Times from Collection to Submissions, and the SDTMIG for more information.

This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH END DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable MLENDTC in ISO 8601 format.
The time when the subject ended/stopped taking the meal or food product represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss).
Standardized Meal Name
This field does not typically appear on the CRF. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process. Equivalent to a standardized name in a published or sponsor-defined dictionaries.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
The dictionary or sponsor-defined standardized text description of the topic variable (MLTRT) or the modified topic variable (MLMODIFY), if applicable.
Modified Reported Term
This is not a data collection field that will appear on the CRF itself. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
If the value for MLTRT is modified for coding purposes, then the modified text is placed here.
Study Identifier
[Protocol/Study]

Although this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or the EDC system. This field can be included into the database or created during SDTM-based dataset creation before submission.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
A unique identifier for a study.
Study Site Identifier
Site (Identifier)

Paper: This is typically pre-printed in the header of each CRF page for single-site studies. For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be pre-printed on the CRFs that are shipped to each site. \n EDC: This should be pre-populated.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
A unique identifier for a site within a study.
Subject Identifier for the Study
[Subject/Participant] (Identifier)
Record the identifier for the subject.

Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be system generated. This CDASH variable is typically collected in all CDASH domains. However, this CDASH variable is populated only in the SDTMIG DM domain. For more information, refer to the SDTMIG.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
A unique subject identifier within a site and a study.
Any Procedures Performed
Any Procedures
Indicate if the subject had any surgical, therapeutic or diagnostic procedures. If "Yes", include the appropriate details where indicated on the CRF.
The intent/purpose of collecting this field is to help with data cleaning and monitoring. It provides verification that all other fields on the CRF were deliberately left blank.
Does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM annotated CRF indicates that this field is NOT SUBMITTED.
An indication of whether the subject had any procedures performed.
Procedure Category
[Procedure Category]; NULL
Record the procedure category, if not pre-printed on the CRF.

Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a pre-printed category value on the CRF, and not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Category" can be included as the column header.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
A grouping of topic-variable values based on user-defined characteristics.
Procedure Subcategory
[Procedure Subcategory]; NULL
Record the procedure subcategory, if not pre-printed on the CRF.

Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be pre-printed on the CRF or screen and prepopulated in the data management system. This is not typically a question to which the site would provide an answer. PRSCAT can only be used if there is a PRCAT and it must be a subcategorization of PRCAT.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
A sub-division of the PRCAT values based on user-defined characteristics.
Procedure Sponsor-Defined Identifier
[Sponsor defined]
If collected on the CRF, sponsor may insert instructions to ensure each record has a unique identifier.

Because SPID is a sponsor-defined identifier, conformance to Question Text or Item Prompt is not applicable. Typically used as an identifier in a data query to communicate clearly to the site the specific record in question or to reconcile procedure records with medical history and/or with AEs. May be used to record pre-printed number (e.g., line number, record number) on the CRF. This field may be populated by the sponsor's data collection system.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.

A sponsor-defined identifier. In CDASH, This is typically used for pre-printed or auto-generated numbers on the CRF, or any other type of identifier that does not already have a defined CDASH identifier field.
Reported Name of Procedure
[Procedure Name]; (Specify) Other
Record only one procedure per line.
In most cases, the verbatim procedure names or therapy will be coded to a standard dictionary (e.g., MedDRA, SNOMED) after the data have been collected on the CRF.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
The verbatim surgical, therapeutic, or diagnostic procedure's name.
Standardized Procedure Name
[Standardized Procedure Name]

This is typically not a data collection field that will appear on the CRF. If the sponsor chooses to code the procedure, the sponsor will populate this through the coding process. If PRPRESP is used, and the information about a specific standardized procedure name is being solicited, the data from PRTRT may map directly to the SDTMIG PRDECOD variable.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
The dictionary or sponsor-defined standardized text description of PRTRT, or the modified topic variable (PRMODIFY), if applicable.
Modified Procedure Name
This is not a data collection field that will appear on the CRF. If the sponsor chooses to code the procedure, the sponsor will populate this through the coding process.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
If the value for PRTRT is modified for coding purposes, then the modified text is placed here.
Procedure Prespecified

For pre-specified interventions, a hidden field on a CRF defaulted to "Y", or added during the SDTM dataset creation. If a study collects both pre-specified and free-text interventions, the value of PRPRESP should be "Y" for all prespecified interventions and null for interventions reported as free text.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
An indication that a specific intervention or a group of interventions is pre-specified on a CRF.
Procedure Occurrence
[PRDECOD/PRTRT] Performed
Indicate if [specific procedure] was performed by checking Yes or No.

PROCCUR is used to report the occurrence of a prespecified procedure or a group of procedures. PROCCUR is not used for spontaneously free text-reported procedures. The site should be able to indicate that the response was not asked or answered.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. If the response was not asked or answered, populate the SDTMIG variable PRSTAT with "NOT DONE".
An indication of whether a pre-specified procedure (PRTRT) happened when information about the occurrence of a specific intervention is solicited.
Procedure Reason for Occur Value
Reason (Not) Performed
Indicate why the procedure was or wasnot performed.

The reason the scheduled procedure was or was not performed may be chosen from a sponsor-defined codelist (e.g., SUBJECT REFUSED) or entered as free text. When --REASOC is used, --OCCUR must also be populated in the SDTM dataset with a value of "Y" or "N".

This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM = "PRREASOC" and SUPPPR.QLABEL="Reason for Occur Value". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of non-standard variables (NSVs) in SDTM domains.
An explanation for why a scheduled procedure did or did not occur.
Procedure Reason Not Done
Reason not done
Provide the reason why the procedure was not done.

The reason the data are not available may be chosen from a sponsor-defined list (e.g., broken equipment, subject refused) or entered as free text. When PRREASND is used, the SDTMIG variable PRSTAT should also be populated in the SDTM-based dataset. The value "NOT DONE" here indicates that the subject was not questioned/data was not collected. It does not mean that the subject did not have the procedure.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
An explanation for why the data are not available.
Prior Procedure
Prior to [PRSTTPT]; Prior to study
Check if the procedure was started before the specified point in time.
See Section 3.7, Mapping Relative Times from Collection to Submissions, and and the SDTMIG for more information about mapping relative times..

This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. May be used to populate a value into an SDTM relative timing variable such as PRSTRF or PRSTRTPT. When populating PRSTRF, or PRSTRTPT, if the value of the CDASH field PRPRIOR is "Y" a value from the CDISC CT (STENRF) may be used. When PRPRIOR refers to the Study Reference Period (defined in DM.RFSTDTC to DM.RFENDTC) the SDTM variable PRSTRF should be populated. When PRPRIOR is compared to another time point, the SDTM variables PRSTRTPT and PRSTTPT should be used. Note: PRSTRTPT must refer to the time-point anchor described in PRSTTPT.
Indication the procedure occurred prior to [PRSTTPT] or prior to the date in DM.RFSTDTC.
Procedure Start Date
(Start) Date

Record the date the procedure was started or performed using this format (DD-MON-YYYY). Procedures performed during the study are expected to have a complete start date. Prior procedures that are exclusionary should have both a start and end date.
The preferred method is to collect a complete Start Date. Partial dates (e.g., providing year only) for procedures started a considerable amount of time prior to the start of study are acceptable.

This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH START DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable PRSTDTC in ISO 8601 format.
The date or start date of when the procedure started or was performed, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Ongoing Procedure
Ongoing (as of the [study-specific timepoint or period])
Indicate if the procedure has not ended at the time of data collection and the end date should be left blank.

Completed to indicate that the procedure has not stopped at the time point defined by the study. The purpose of collecting this field is to help with data cleaning and monitoring; this field provides further confirmation that the End Date was deliberately left blank. See Section 3.7, Mapping Relative Times from Collection to Submissions, and and SDTMIG for more information about mapping relative times.

This does not map directly to an SDTM variable. May be used to populate a value into an SDTMIG relative timing variable such as PRENRF or PRENRTPT. When populating PRENRF, if the value of PRONGO is "Y", the value of "DURING", "AFTER" or "DURING/AFTER" may be used. When populating PRENRTPT, if the value of PRONGO is "Y", the value of "ONGOING" may be used. When PRONGO refers to the Study Reference Period (defined in DM.RFSTDTC to DM.RFENDTC) the SDTM variable PRENRF should be populated. When PRONGO is used in conjunction with another time point, the SDTM variables PRENRTPT and PRENTPT should be used. Note: PRENRTPT must refer to a time point anchor described in PRENTPT.
Indication the procedure is ongoing when no end date is provided.
Procedure End Date
(End) Date
Record the end date of the procedure using this format (DD-MON-YYYY). If the procedure has not ended, leave this field blank and populate PRONGO as "Y".

The assumption is that sponsors should either have an end date or will indicate that the procedure was ongoing at the time of collection or at the end of the study. However, in cases where the end date can be determined from dates collected elsewhere in the CRF it is not necessary to include an end date in the CRF. For example, if the procedure is started and stopped within the same day, the end date will be the same as the start date.

This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH END DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTM variable PRENDTC in ISO 8601 format.
The end date of the procedure, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Procedure Indication
Indication

Record the reason the procedure was performed based on clinical investigator's evaluation. If performed to treat a condition, and a diagnosis was made, the indication should be the diagnosis. If performed to treat a condition, and no diagnosis was made, the indication should be the signs and symptoms. If taken as prophylaxis, report as "Prophylaxis for" and include a description of the condition(s).

This additional information is collected on the CRF when the sponsor wants to capture the reason(s) why a procedure was performed. This information can then be used as deemed appropriate for coding, analysis (e.g., in the classification of procedures), for reconciling the procedures performed on a subject with their provided medical history, and/or AEs/SAEs as part of the data clean-up and monitoring process.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
The condition, disease, symptom, or disorder that the procedure was used to address or investigate (e.g., why the therapy was taken or administered, why the procedure was performed).
Related Adverse Event ID
Related Adverse Event Identifier
Record the identifier of the adverse event for which this procedure was performed.

The intent is to establish a link between the adverse event and the procedure performed for the adverse event. PRAENO can be used to identify a relationship between records in the PR dataset and records in the AE dataset. See the SDTMIG for information on RELREC.
This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission datasets, may be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in the AE domain.
Identifier for the adverse event that is the indication for this procedure.
Related Medical History Event ID
Related Medical History Event Identifier
Record the identifier of the medical history event for which this procedure was performed.

The intent is to establish a link between the medical history condition and the procedure undergone for the medical history condition. PRMHNO can be used to identify a relationship between records in the PR dataset and records in the MH dataset. See the SDTMIG for information on RELREC.
This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission datasets, may be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in the MH domain.
Identifier for the medical history event that is the indication for this procedure.
Procedure Dose Description
[Dose/Amount]
Record the [dose/amount] of [PRTRT] per administered.

Defining this data collection field as a dose text field allows for flexibility in capturing dose entries as numbers, text or ranges. The data collected in this dose text-format field should be separated or mapped to either SDTMIG PRDOSE if numeric or PRDOSTXT if text.
This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. Numeric values map to PRDOSE in SDTM. Non-numeric values (e.g., 200-400) map to PRDOSTXT in SDTM.
The dose/amount administered during the procedure.
Procedure Dose Unit
Unit
Record the unit for the amount of [PRTRT] performed or administered.
When sponsors collect data for amount of PRTRT performed or administered, the unit should be collected as well (as applicable).
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
The unit for intended dose/amount for PRDOSE, PRDOSTOT, or PRDOSTXT.
Procedure Frequency per Interval
Frequency
Record how often the procedure was performed.
This may be collected if it cannot be determined from other sources or if there are multiple options. Usually expressed as the number of procedures given per a specific interval.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
The number/amount of the procedure that was given/administered/taken during a specific interval.
Procedure Route of Administration
Route
Provide the route of administration for the procedure.
This additional information may be important to collect on the CRF when the sponsor would want to capture a procedure's route of administration for comparative analysis purposes.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
The route of administration of the procedure.
Location of Procedure
Anatomical Location
Record the body location where the procedure was performed.
Collected when the sponsor needs to identify the specific anatomical location (e.g., Liver for the Biopsy). LAT, DIR, PORTOT are used to further describe the anatomical location.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
A description of the anatomical location of an procedure (e.g., location of a biopsy).
Procedure Laterality
Side
Record the side of the anatomical location where the procedure was administered.

Further details the laterality of the location where the procedure was administered/taken. This may be pre-printed or collected. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Qualifier for anatomical location, further detailing side of the body for the procedure administration.
Procedure Directionality
Directionality
Record the direction of the anatomical location where the procedure was administered.

May be pre-printed or collected when the sponsor needs to identify the directionality of the anatomical location. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Qualifier further detailing the position of the anatomical location, relative to the center of the body, organ, or specimen.
Procedure Portion or Totality
Portion or Totality
Record the portion of the body location that was treated.
Collected when the sponsor needs to identify the specific portionality for the anatomical locations. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Qualifier for anatomical location, further detailing the distribution (i.e., arrangement of, apportioning of).
Procedure Fasting Status
Fasting
Record whether the subject was fasting prior to the procedure being performed.
This information is collected when the procedure may be affected by whether the subject was fasting. This may not be relevant for all procedures.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
An indication that the subject has abstained from food/water for the specified amount of time.
Procedure Intended Dose Regimen
Intended Procedure Regimen
Record the intended regimen for the procedure to be performed.

The regimen information may further clarify the dose administration and dose frequency (e.g., TWO WEEKS ON, TWO WEEKS OFF). This may be prespecified or collected. The sponsor may wish to create a codelist to collect this data consistently.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
The text description of the (intended) schedule or regimen for the procedure.
Procedure Adjusted
(Dose) Adjusted
Record if the procedure was adjusted from planned.

Typically, the intent/purpose of collecting this field is to help with data cleaning and monitoring. It provides verification that the associate field on the CRF (PRADJ) was deliberately left blank. However, the sponsor may collect whether the procedure dose/amount was adjusted, without collecting the reason for the change.

When PRADJ is collected, does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM annotated CRF indicates that this field is NOT SUBMITTED. When PRADJ is not collected, the sponsor may submit this variable as a SUPPQ.
An indication of whether the procedure dose/amount was adjusted.
Reason for Procedure Adjustment
Reason Adjusted
Record why the procedure dose was adjusted from planned.
Captures the reason the PRTRT dose was changed or modified. The reason may be chosen from a sponsor-defined list (e.g., adverse event, insufficient response) or entered as free text.
Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Description of or explanation for why a procedure dose/amount was adjusted.
Completed Procedure
Completed [PR Intervention Topic]
Record if the subject completed the intended regimen.
Depending on how the PTTRT dose details are collected via the CRF/eCRF, it may be possible to derive those data if the regimen data are collected.

This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM= "PRTRTCMP" and SUPPPR.QLABEL="Treatment Completed". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains.
Indication of whether the subject completed the intended regimen.
Procedure Interrupted
Procedure Interrupted
Record if the procedure was interrupted.

Provides a definitive response regarding any procedure interruption. The intent/purpose of collecting this field is to help with data cleaning and monitoring when the duration of the interruption is collected. In some situations, if the actual duration of the interruption is not collected, or not derived, this information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset.
Does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM annotated CRF indicates that this field is NOT SUBMITTED.
An indication of whether the procedure was interrupted.
Reason Procedure Interrupted
Reason Procedure Interrupted
Record the reason the procedure was interrupted.
This CDASH field is use to collected the reason why an intervention was interrupted. The sponsor may define controlled terminology.

This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM="PRITRPRS" and SUPPPR.QLABEL ="Reason Intervention Interrupted". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains.
An explanation for why the intervention was interrupted.
Procedure Interruption Duration
(Interruption) Duration
Record how long the procedure was interrupted before it resumed.

This field is used to collect the duration of procedure interruption. In some situations, the duration of the interruption may not be collected but calculated from the procedure start and end times recorded elsewhere in the CRF.

This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM="PRITRPD" and SUPPPR.QLABEL= "Interruption Duration". Concatenate the collected procedure interruption duration and the duration unit components and create PRITRPD using ISO 8601 Period format. Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains.
The collected duration of the procedure interruption.
Procedure Interruption Duration Units
(Interruption Duration) Unit
Record the unit for the duration of interruption of the procedure.
The unit should be collected as a qualifier to the number for duration.

This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM="PRITRPD" and SUPPPR.QLABEL= "Interruption Duration". Concatenate the collected procedure interruption duration and the duration unit components and create PRITRPD using ISO 8601 Period format. Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains.
The unit for the collected duration of the procedure interruption.
Procedure Lowest Level Term

This field does not typically appear on the CRF. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process. This is applicable to items using MedDRA coding. Rationale for adding coding variables to CDASH is to provide a more complete data management package. This variable could be used in the PR domain for coding. Another dictionary can be used and the appropriate coding elements added, if appropriate, in the SUPPPR.QVAL dataset.

This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM="PRLLT" and SUPPPR.QLABEL="Lower Level Term". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains. Sponsors should include an Origin column in the SUPPQ dataset to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED".
The dictionary-derived text description of the lowest level term.
Procedure Lowest Level Term Code

This field does not typically appear on the CRF. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process. This is applicable to items using MedDRA coding. Rationale for adding coding variables to CDASH is to provide a more complete data management package. This variable could be used in the PR domain for MedDRA coding. Other dictionaries can be used and the appropriate coding elements added, if appropriate, in the SUPPPR.QVAL dataset.

This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM="PRLLTCD" and SUPPPR.QLABEL="Lower Level Term Code". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains. Sponsors should include an Origin column in the SUPPQ dataset to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED".
The dictionary-derived code for the lowest level term.
Procedure Preferred Term Code

This field does not typically appear on the CRF. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process. This is applicable to items using MedDRA coding. Rationale for adding coding variables to CDASH is to provide a more complete data management package. This variable could be used in the PR domain for MedDRA coding. Other dictionaries can be used and the appropriate coding elements added, if appropriate, in the SUPPPR.QVAL dataset.

This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR.QVAL dataset where SUPPPR.QNAM="PRPTCD" and SUPPPR.QLABEL= "Preferred Term Code Lower Level Term Code". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVsin SDTM domains. Sponsors should include an Origin column in the SUPPQ dataset to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED".
The dictionary-derived code for the preferred term.
Procedure High Level Term

This is not a data collection field that would appear on the CRF. Sponsors populate this through the coding process. This is applicable to items using MedDRA coding. Rationale for adding coding variables to CDASH is to provide a more complete data management package. This variable could be used in the PR domain for MedDRA coding. Other dictionaries can be used and the appropriate coding elements added, if appropriate, in the SUPPPR.QVAL dataset.

This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM="PRHLT" and SUPPPR.QLABEL="High Level Term". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains. Sponsors should include an Origin column in the SUPPQ dataset to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED".
The dictionary-derived text description of the high level term for the primary system organ class (SOC).
Procedure High Level Term Code

This is not a data collection field that would appear on the CRF. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process. This is applicable to items using MedDRA coding. Rationale for adding coding variables to CDASH is to provide a more complete data management package. This variable could be used in the PR domain for MedDRA coding. Other dictionaries can be used and the appropriate coding elements added, if appropriate, in the SUPPPR.QVAL dataset.

This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR.QVAL dataset where SUPPPR.QNAM="PRHLTCD" and SUPPPR.QLABEL="High Level Term Code". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains. Sponsors should include an Origin in the define metadata document to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED".

Other dictionaries can be used and the appropriate coding elements added, if appropriate, in the SUPPPR.QVAL dataset.

This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM="PRHLTGT" and SUPPPR.QLABEL="High Level Group Term". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains. Sponsors should include an Origin column in the SUPPQ dataset to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED".

Other dictionaries can be used and the appropriate coding elements added, if appropriate, in the SUPPPR.QVAL dataset.
